Award.AwardTitle: Development & Applications of Density Functional Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Weitao Yang of Duke University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop new electronic structure methods. Electronic structure calculations provide fundamental information about molecular structure and molecular interactions, with broad applications in science and engineering. Because of its efficiency and its good accuracy for many applications, density functional theory (DFT) is the method of choice for such calculations for large systems. There are, however, many important applications where current DFT methods do not give accurate results. This proposal aims to build on the insight and progress made recently in order to develop the next-generation density functional approximations for accurate and efficient determination of electronic structure of large systems that are found in biology, chemistry, physics, engineering and nano-science and technology.

With various theoretical strategies, the research effort will focus on exploring the functional forms needed to approximate exact conditions with fractional charges and spins, following two complementary directions: (1) Constructing approximations from first-principles many-body theory, particularly via the pairing matrix fluctuation formulation and (2) Imposing known exact conditions in terms of fractional variables on commonly-used functionals. The functionals developed will be theoretically sound, and have minimal delocalization and static correlation errors. They will be accurate for a broad range of applications and advance the frontiers of DFT towards the correct descriptions of thermochemistry, reaction kinetics, charge transfer, organic and transition metal molecules to bulk materials. The research approach will be based on derivation from theory and physics, using the minimal number of parameters . The proposed work should contribute to the progress of theoretical and computational chemistry in becoming an equal partner with other more traditional fields of chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Density functional theory (DFT) of electronic structure has made an unparalleled impact on the application of quantum mechanics to interesting and challenging problems in chemistry, biology, physics and engineering. The number of applications is huge and growing rapidly. DFT plays a central role in simulations across sciences and engineering: the understanding and design of catalytic processes in enzymes and zeolites, electron transport, solar energy harvesting and conversion, drug design in medicine, just to list a few. Our project has been focused on making the theoretical prediction from DFT more accurate and efficient. We have made significant progress in the development of density functional approximations and the particle-particle random phase approximation, for both ground and excited states.  

We developed a local scaling correction scheme by imposing the Perdew-Parr-Levy-Balduz exact linearity condition to local regions of a system. This approach has been much improved with the latest development of LOSC (localized orbital scaling correction) and has been extended in the fractional spin correction for strong correlation.

Our laboratory has lead the development of pp-RPA (particle-particle random phase approximation) for calculations of molecular excited states. Starting from an (N ± 2)-electron single-determinant reference, we obtain excitations for the N-electron system through the pairing matrix fluctuation, which contains information on two-electron addition/removal processes. While pp-RPA is a known theory for describing pairing excitations based on Hartree-Fock theory, and has been used in nuclear physics for describing nuclear correlation energy and in molecular physics for describing two-electron removal energetics of molecules in in the past, our work was the first to apply pp-RPA for electron correlation and also first to calculate neutral electronic excitations by shifting the reference to a ( N-2 ) -electron system and use density functional theory to describe the ground state of the ( N-2 ) reference systems.

We have applied pp-RPA to a broad range of electronic excitations in molecules. For single excitations where conventional TDDFT (time-dependent DFT) works well, compared to TDDFT, there is no systematic bias for the pp-RPA with the mean signed error close to zero. The mean absolute error of pp-RPA with B3LYP or PBE reference is similar to that of TDDFT, which suggests that the pp-RPA is a comparable method to TDDFT for large molecules.  For many other excitations where TDDFT fails, pp-RPA provides accurate description for diradicals and disjoint diradicals, conical intersection, and charge transfer systems.

After establishing the validity of pp-RPA, we applied pp-RPA to polyacences. Higher acenes have drawn much attention as promising organic semiconductors with versatile electronic properties. However, the nature of their ground state and electronic excited states is still not fully clear. Their unusual chemical reactivity and instability are the main obstacles for experimental studies, and the potentially prominent diradical character, which might require a multireference description in such large systems, hinders theoretical investigations. We provided a detailed answer with the the pp-RPA calculation. The 1Ag ground states of acenes up to decacene are on the closed-shell side of the diradical continuum, whereas the ground state of undecacene and dodecacene tilts more to the open-shell side with a growing polyradical character. In particular, our prediction on the mainly closed-shell nature of the ground state of nonacene has been verified in recent experiments (ACS Nano, 2017; DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.7b04728).
